page.title: List of United States cities by population

revisions.rev:
{{United States Cities Labeled Map}}
The following is a '''list of the most populous incorporated places in the United States'''. As defined by the [[United States Census Bureau]], an "[[incorporated place]]" includes a variety of designations, including a [[city]], [[town]], [[village]], [[borough]], and [[municipality]].{{Cref2|a}} Some [[census-designated place]]s may also be included in the Census Bureau's listing of incorporated places.{{cref2|b|1}}{{cref2|c|1}} [[consolidated cityâcounty|Consolidated city-counties]] represent a distinct type of government that includes the entire population of a county, or county equivalent. Some consolidated city-counties, however, include multiple incorporated places. This list presents only that portion (or "balance") of such consolidated city-counties that are not a part of another incorporated place. Note that this list refers only to the population of individual municipalities within their [[City limits|defined limits]], which does not include other municipalities or unincorporated [[suburb]]an areas within [[urban agglomeration]]s. A different ranking is evident when considering [[Table of United States Metropolitan Statistical Areas|U.S. metropolitan area populations]]. ==Incorporated places over 100,000 population== The following table lists the incorporated places in the United States with a population on April 1, 2010, of more than 100,000 as counted in the [[2010 United States Census]].{{cite web | url = http://factfinder2.census.gov | title=American FactFinder|publisher=U.S. Census Bureau}} Land area and population density are also provided to the nearest tenth to give a general idea of how densely packed each city is. Since the U.S. Census Bureau typically does not rank the cities of [[Insular area|U.S. territories]] along with those of the [[U.S. state|fifty states]] and the [[Washington, D.C.|District of Columbia]], the cities of [[Puerto Rico]] with populations greater than 100,000 are listed separately [[#Puerto Rico|below]]. A detailed discussion on this subject can be found at [[New England town#Census treatment of the New England town system]].}} {{Cnote2|b|n=2|[[Hawaii]] has no incorporated municipalities other than the [[Honolulu County, Hawaii|City and County of Honolulu]], which actually includes the entire island of [[Oahu]]. In accordance with Hawaiian law, the U.S. Census Bureau defines the state's "cities" and "towns" as [[census-designated place]]s (CDPs). The Census Bureau defines Honolulu CDP as the portion of the City and County that is coextensive with the Judicial District of Honolulu. Honolulu CDP is what is generally thought of as the "city" of [[Honolulu]], and its population is used here and in other population comparisons. If the entire population of the City and County were included, Honolulu would place 10th on the list above with a 2010 estimated population of 953,207.{{cite web |url=http://factfinder2.census.gov/faces/tableservices/jsf/pages/productview.xhtml?pid=DEC_10_DP_DPDP1&prodType=table |title= Profile of General Population and Housing Characteristics: 2010 |accessdate=2011-07-28 |publisher=United States Census Bureau, Population Division}}}} {{Cnote2|c|n=2|[[Arlington County, Virginia|Arlington CDP, Virginia]], is coextensive with Arlington County. [[Virginia]] law forbids the creation of cities in counties with over 1,000 people per square mile, which Arlington County exceeds. Thus, the entire county is considered by the Census Bureau as one CDP. While not incorporated as a municipality, Arlington is included in the Census Bureau's annual list of incorporated places and is retained in the above list.}} {{Cnote2|d|n=2|[[Baltimore]] and [[St. Louis, Missouri|St. Louis]] are [[independent city|independent cities]] that are not a part of any particular [[County (United States)|county]].}} {{Cnote2|e|n=4|Cities in [[Virginia]], excepting [[Arlington County, Virginia|Arlington]], are all [[independent city|independent cities]] that are not a part of any particular [[County (United States)|county]].}} {{Cnote2|f|n=3|Cities in [[Virginia]] (continued), excepting [[Arlington County, Virginia|Arlington]], are all [[independent city|independent cities]] that are not a part of any particular [[County (United States)|county]].}} {{Cnote2|g|n=5|[[Indianapolis|Indianapolis, Indiana]]; [[Louisville, Kentucky]]; [[Nashville, Tennessee]]; [[Augusta, Georgia]]; and [[Athens, Georgia]] are [[consolidated cityâcounty|consolidated cityâcounties]].
